Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Story:
My phone buzzed with two messages almost at the same time. My sister, Maya, had just gotten her first big promotion and wanted to celebrate with a family dinner on Friday night. She wrote, “I really want you there. It wouldn’t be the same without you.” I could almost hear her excitement through the screen, and I knew how much it meant to her that I show up, just like she always did for me.

A minute later, Alex texted, “How about Friday for our date night? I’ve been looking forward to spending some real time together.” We’d both been so busy lately, and this week was finally open for both of us. He’d been patient, but I could sense how much he wanted this time—just us, no distractions.

I stared at my phone, feeling the pressure build in my chest. I wanted to be the supportive sister Maya expected, to cheer her on and make her feel special. But I also wanted to be the attentive girlfriend Alex deserved, making our relationship a priority. The weight of their expectations pulled me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know how to choose without letting someone down.
